Brenda Manuel, retired lead for Diversity and Equal Opportunity, shares advice on leading and inspiring your team: https://t.co/TM1oRz8YAq “People are always watching. Hold yourself accountable. Things that you say you’re going to do, go out and do those things.”

Dr. Woodrow Whitlow, retired lead for Mission Support, shares the most important lesson he’s learned about leadership: https://t.co/qfQehArZya “A career as a researcher, and a center director and associate administrator is not so bad at NASA after all.”

— Dr. Woodrow Whitlow, retired lead for Mission Support, reflects on his career and his childhood dream jobs. https://t.co/yCoO0c3N7a “I tried to look at different opportunities within NASA that would allow me to gain different perspectives... and as a result, I was always volunteering to do something that I hadn’t done before.”

— Brenda Manuel, retired lead for Diversity and Equal Opportunity https://t.co/zp7ZNkcAtt “Managing change is a big part of developing management skills, and one of the ways that you solve that is by building relationships with other people involved on your team.” 

— Hal Walker, Jr., one of the leads for Apollo 11’s lunar laser ranging experiment https://t.co/XRpGNe8rUI “People come with different backgrounds, different baselines… so the big part of leadership is serving those folks and creating that environment so they can do amazing things.”

▪️PGT = Pistol Grip Tool (drill)
▪️BRT = Body Restraint Tether (cord)

@VP Thank you, Madam Vice President. Mary W. Jackson opened doors for countless women so that they, too, can make a difference. Her legacy inspires us to soar higher.
With a countdown to unveil the sign at the end of today's ceremony, @NASA_Langley atmospheric scientist Yolanda Shea presents the Mary W. Jackson NASA Headquarters building. https://t.co/dmH8TAy0HW

"Knowing the woman I loved, honored, & respected all my life has a statue at Hampton University that I can go visit [...] and now in Washington, DC representing NASA's Headquarters, there's no words to explain how I'm feeling right now." - Mary W. "She was that type of person who would do anything for anybody, no questions asked. Whatever you needed, whether it was finance, whether it was food, whether it was love, whether it was a place to live." -  Wanda Jackson, Mary W. Jackson's granddaughter, remembers her. https://t.co/51T54RrxyX

"This piece was about bringing to life Mary Jackson's power and impact, while celebrating her great achievements, and depicting just how out of this world she is." — Visual artist, illustrator, & animator Tenbeete Solomon (@TRAPBOB) presents her artwork honoring Mary W. “I wanted to create a piece that represented, and celebrated and honored Mary W. “May her name, as well as her legacy, forever be a reminder [...] that we as a people have only been able to touch the stars because of ancestors like her, who had the courage, who had the resilience to overcome every obstacle placed in their way.” — Dr. @HenryLouisGates https://t.co/KYtZeCDAiy

"She made a very special effort to meet these young aerospace engineers, to welcome them, to show them hospitality, and to give them advice."  — Dr. Christine Darden, retired @NASA_Langley engineer, on Mary W. “President John F. Kennedy said something like, a nation reveals itself not only by those it produces, but also by those it honors, and those it remembers. Naming this building after Mary Jackson reveals a lot about our country.” — Rep. @BobbyScott https://t.co/sTUCTcY3Vz

"We need everybody. I mean everybody - every bright mind that's willing."

— @NASA_Langley director Clayton Turner wraps up today's discussion with his thoughts on leadership and contributing to NASA's mission. https://t.co/ORjPtq13uB

Answering a video question, @NASA_Johnson deputy director Vanessa Wyche on telling your story to encourage others:

“When I saw [Hidden Figures], I was like, ‘oh wow. There were women who had gone through this thirty years before I was going through the same things.’” https://t.co/Wdw1yxAOKJ

“Even if you don’t have a formal mentoring program, I encourage folks to get a mentor. Somebody you can learn from.”

@NASA_Johnson deputy director Vanessa Wyche shares thoughts on how to aim high with your career: https://t.co/whBGk4GeFs

“You have to make sure that your team understands that whatever you do, it has to be done in excellence.”

Brenda Manuel, retired lead for Diversity and Equal Opportunity, shares advice on leading and inspiring your team: https://t.co/TM1oRz8YAq

“People are always watching. Hold yourself accountable. Things that you say you’re going to do, go out and do those things.”

Dr. Woodrow Whitlow, retired lead for Mission Support, shares the most important lesson he’s learned about leadership: https://t.co/qfQehArZya

“A career as a researcher, and a center director and associate administrator is not so bad at NASA after all.”

— Dr. Woodrow Whitlow, retired lead for Mission Support, reflects on his career and his childhood dream jobs. https://t.co/yCoO0c3N7a

“I tried to look at different opportunities within NASA that would allow me to gain different perspectives... and as a result, I was always volunteering to do something that I hadn’t done before.”

— Brenda Manuel, retired lead for Diversity and Equal Opportunity https://t.co/zp7ZNkcAtt

“Managing change is a big part of developing management skills, and one of the ways that you solve that is by building relationships with other people involved on your team.” 

— Hal Walker, Jr., one of the leads for Apollo 11’s lunar laser ranging experiment https://t.co/XRpGNe8rUI

“People come with different backgrounds, different baselines… so the big part of leadership is serving those folks and creating that environment so they can do amazing things.”

@NASA_Langley director Clayton Turner reflects on how effective leadership helps to lift others up: https://t.co/mA60RAMo6M

“Looking the number of people that we have in leadership… it makes me feel like we have accomplished quite a lot.” 

@NASA_Johnson deputy director Vanessa Wyche comments on the legacy and impact of Black representation at NASA: https://t.co/T1rxTMy2j3

@stoverkill To confirm, we do not have a secret Moon base. With our #Artemis program, we’ll work with our partners to establish a long-term presence on the Moon at the lunar South Pole by the end of the decade.

@theassambler Moonlight is actually reflected sunlight. And much like Earth, the Moon has day and night, but one lunar day = one Earth month! Half of the Moon is always lit by the Sun, but the part that we see changes throughout the month. https://t.co/W3m3vcRnKK https://t.co/fE3QMesKv1

What do Albert Einstein, GPS, & a pair of stars 200,000 trillion miles away have in common?
